article_title: Cruz campaigns like a moral crusader

article_metadata.description: For close to a minute, only the rapid fire clicks of news cameras could be heard echoing through the cavernous ballroom.  Down in the polls and jostling for position in an increasingly crowded GOP field, the conservative rock star from Texas has demonstrated one unique trait since opening his presidential bid in mid-March at a raucous Christian convocation at Liberty University in Virginia.  Railing against same-sex marriage, the Supreme Court, the Senate GOP leadership and the special-interest lobbies he terms the “Washington cartel,” the Cruz campaign increasingly has taken on the aura of a tent revival.  [...] any further slippage could cost Cruz or Perry a place on the debate stage Aug. 6 in Cleveland, where Fox News organizers announced they will only include the top 10 in the national polls.  Ferraro represents a grass-roots cohort that has helped the Cruz campaign and a separate political action committee raise more than $51 million — enough to compete in the early voting states of Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina, where he has focused his efforts.  Cruz’s big gamble is that the niche of tea party and religious activists he’s courting, however narrow it may be, could prove to be the sweet spot of the 2016 GOP presidential primaries.  Much like in the surprise Texas U.S. Senate primary in 2012 that brought Cruz to national attention, the most likely GOP voters flow from the activist base.  With more than a dozen legitimate contenders sweeping through the early states, it won’t take an absolute majority in any one contest to perform well and build momentum.  [...] the same fragmentation that has kept a clear front-runner from emerging in the polls also is holding Cruz in the low single digits — except in Texas, where a recent University of Texas poll gave him a commanding lead over Perry and the rest of the GOP field.  All three will be at this week’s gathering of religious conservatives in Ames, Iowa, an event sponsored by the Family Leader, a Christian-centered group that plays an outsized role in the caucuses.  Since we do, the most natural fit for Mr. Cruz after that is the evangelical bracket.  Cruz likes to bring up the legal battle over religious prerogatives that came to a head recently in Indiana, where the Legislature passed a law that could allow businesses to turn away gay and lesbian customers on religious grounds.  “We can rally together and talk about the flag all we want,” Bright said on the Senate floor, turning the issue back to the U.S. Supreme Court decision on same-sex marriage.  Talk of the devil might place the Cruz campaign on the fringes of modern secular society, but its echoes of old-time religion could travel a long way in a party whose main strongholds increasingly are in the rural South.
article_metadata.author.name: By Kevin Diaz, Washington Bureau
